job_title: College Adviser in Lansing, MI
pros: This is an Americorps position, so you are technically doing a service year, not working, and at the end will receive a service award equal to the amount of the Pell Grant that you can use towards education. This is geared towards recent college grads, specifically of Michigan State University, and you are meant to work with high school seniors and help them figure out their life path while you figure out your own for 1-2 years.
cons: Your experience will heavily depend on the school you are placed in so it can be hard to generalize. Some of the schools are large and urban, some are tiny and rural, and they have varying amounts of funds and resources. You apply directly to which school you want to work with so you have some say in what type of school district you’d prefer to work with and the staff will help you figure this out, but if you’ve never worked in schools before it can be tough to realize what schools will have which resources.

job_title: Graduate Assistant
pros: The pay is adequate for living expenses in the area. Very beautiful campus and lots of nature activities to do in the area. Graduate students are unionized and have lots of protections here that may not be guaranteed at other universities. The university has been expanding a lot with tons of new buildings going up in recent years.
cons: University administrators can be slow to do anything meaningful and require a lot of pressure from faculty, students, and the community to act quickly, which was the case with ousting Stephen Hsu as the vice president of research due to ethical concerns about his company Genomic Prediction and general eugenics views. MSU cut salaries and retirement plans of faculty when it was expected that the Covid-19 epidemic would severely cripple the university finances, but when that turned out to be false, MSU tried to keep retirement cuts in place. There is no university hospital, so health research is hampered in general and medical students must perform their rotations at partner hospitals in the area.

job_title: Educational Leader in Novi, MI
pros: The experience is great. You learn a lot, plus get access to MSU job postings before non-employees do. You get to educate schoolchildren about scientific topics.
cons:
Other than it being a fun job through MSU, it's not that good of a job. Pay is EXTREMELY low. Requires a college degree, but only pays 15-16/hour (for reference, Aldi's in the area starts at $16/hour. I cannot stress enough how low $15-$16/hour is for Novi.)
Job averages at about 20-29 hours per week. At $15-$16 per hour, that's $1200-$1856 per month (pre-tax). Average cost of rent in Novi is $1200-$1500/month. 

A company that won't even pay for its employees to live in the surrounding area is scummy. I don't care how good of a learning opportunity it is; it's scummy and exploitative. MSU can do better. I know they can do better.

job_title: Building Sanitation Worker in East Lansing, MI
pros: - Comfortable and friendly work environment, you'll have a hard time finding a better workplace environment where everyone can coexist in a professional manner. - Benefits, MSU pays for life, health, and dental insurance I believe, so that's a plus, along with other odds and ends here and there like discounts to travel. - Paid sick, vacation, and personal time, although I believe there could be a bit more personal time, its still a pretty good deal, again especially for the location hard to come by. - Ladder and classes: meaning if you have a desire to learn and better yourself, and not just settle, you can make your way up the hiring ladder and make more money, I personally am wanting to explore this a lot more but it is there, and within a year of working here I was already promoted once for my relationships and work ethic, definitely worth it if you can get in.
cons: -Changes to the unions don't happen often, so what's there is there, and not much would or will be changing it seems, I believe that's why some of the pay rates seem so rock solid despite inflation, people are so comfortable and afraid of change that not much will, well change. - Same problems as everywhere else, inflation increases, pay rates don't. -They make their own employees pay for employee parking, because capitalism I guess. Its not cheap either, like $45 every month just to park at a place I get paid. Which is just dumb, nuff said. -Its on a college campus so traffic can get extra stuffy at times, which makes sense, but location is still technically a con so here it is.

In all the years I have worked. I have never held a postion where if I follow my managers instructions I will eventually NEED to leave my job. But, here we are.

Culture - You wouldn't think that a higher learning institution would have this problem. I experience racism and retaliation first hand at this fine institution.

DEI - at MSU is a DEI book club and occasionally a movie. At least, that's who I saw do the most.

No Advancement - My 2 managers had been at MSU for 20 and 25 years respectively. I had no where to go.

Management - Or lack there of, I had 2 managers that should explain most of it.

Work/Life - Depends on the Mgr. One did not contact outside of business hours and one did so.

Pay - Lower than industry standards.

Parking - I had to pay for parking. (not too unusual but kind of exspensive)

Training - There was none! (over 4 years)

DO YOU NEED MORE!!!

job_title: Graduate Research Fellow in East Lansing, MI
pros: You get a degree you can only maybe use...?
cons:
The graduate program at Michigan State University is, for most departments, an "apprenticeship model." This is a system in which you have, in most cases, a single advisor who controls your time, your wages, and, if you let them, all of your free time and activities (seriously, one advisor told his grad student that he couldn't believe she was getting a dog--when would she have time for that?). Your advisor has more power than you and the administration will, except in cases of incontrovertible, heinous behavior, always side with your advisor over you. Advisors receive no formal training in how to be effective managers and will expect you to work 80+ hours a week on top of your studies.  

Unless you have an actual job that requires (and is paying for) your graduate degree, you probably don't need one. Please do not let yourself get caught up in this racket of a system where they take the smartest, most hard-working minds in the country, over work them, pay them starvation wages, and then expect you to thank them for it for the rest of your life. 

Bonus: Because the term "student" is attached to your position, no employer outside of academia will every consider the years you spend here "experience." You'll have to start at entry-level when you leave.

job_title: Academic Specialist in East Lansing, MI
pros: Good benefits, especially vacation time for specialists and academic staff.
cons:
The pay is sh*t, and the Univesity expects many qualifications for even low level positions.  The University bureaucracy is intolerable.  Management is abhorrently bad and impractical.  Lou Anna Simon is "Ms. Political Correctness" and this attitude is pervasive throughout.  Women and minorities are favored for high-level positions, independent of their qualifications and the availability of suitable, more qualified applicants.  The Unions and University policy prohibit the various units from hiring people they want, and force hiring based on senority, presence on the "lay-off list", and force hiring units to post jobs they have every intention of filling with pre-selected candidates.  This wastes the time and energy of applicants seeking to enter or move up in the University, as well as the time of the hiring unit staff.  

MSU is very much a "spoils system" of promotion - a real "ole boys" network, especially among the academics.   For research based positions, they prefer the young and/or the foreign. Union influence in the University stifles growth, innovation, and job opportunities.

Moreover, the University bureaucracy binds the hands of the research and outreach centers, making it virtually impossible for them to survive and operate effectively.

job_title: Information Technologist in Lansing, MI
pros: Fantastic benefits are a huge plus working at a public university. MSU provides health, dental, substantial 403b matching (the nonprofit version of a 401k) and generous vacation time which increases as you gain years of service. Other fringe benefits include half tuition for any dependent children you have who attend MSU, 14 credits/year of free tuition for support staff employees (at any school in the state!), discounts on area services, and more. MSU has a beautiful campus and is honestly it's a pleasure to head into work every morning.
cons: As a whole MSU is somewhat discombobulated - being a large university can do that. Also, it seems odd that there's no vision insurance offered - that's something I really wish they had. One other downside is that career advancement can depend on the department you're employed in - a smaller department won't offer as many opportunities without first needing a lateral transfer of some kind.

job_title: Information Technologist II (Developer) in East Lansing, MI
pros:
* Relative job stability. Layoffs are rare.
* The new CIO seems competent
cons:
* Employment at MSU was attractive because of its great benefits package, but that package is no longer available to new hires.

* Little to no career advancement

* By and large the only way to get a raise is to get a new position in a different department

job_title: Team Member in Lansing, MI
pros: I have wonderful coworkers and managers. Really like the customers that come in. A lot of them are ”regulars”. A LOT of seniors and retirees. Pretty nice people. The work is super easy and management is very flexible with scheduling.
cons:
Got passed over for a full time position. Let me rephrase that. They hired internally and I wasn’t considered. Which was hurtful because I have been a wonderful employee. I’ve never called off. I bend over backwards for this job. They do acknowledge it. But they knew that I wanted more hours than what I’m getting at the moment. 

A lot of the customers are always trying to haggle for a certain price. Everything there is already super cheap. Most of the seniors are veterans and get super upset that we don’t have a senior or a veterans discount. I don’t get one either so they need to get in line.  Some coworkers get complaints about their customer service. A couple work in my department. These people need to put a smile on their face. Or at least be polite to our customers.

job_title: Research Technician in East Lansing, MI
pros: The Department of Entomology is a great place to work. The faculty, staff, and graduate students are all intelligent and jovial people. They create a friendly workplace environment. The pay and benefits are good and comparable to other universities. You have the opportunity to work with top researchers on projects that will have valuable applications in multiple areas of the economy.
cons: The department survived a reorganization of the college recently, but the administration may attempt to merge it again in the future. Funding is becoming tighter in general at all universities, so the department is feeling the squeeze. Yearly raises have not kept in line with inflation. To meet the administration's expectations of bringing in funding, faculty have focused more on research lately and as a result teaching has suffered.

review_title: PhD candidate in biological sciences at Michigan State University
job_title: PhD Candidate in East Lansing, MI
pros: MSU offers a BioMolecular Sciences gateway PhD program where you apply to BMS and upon acceptance, do 3 lab rotations during your first year. At the end of your first year, you join 1 of 6 PhD programs (cell and molecular biology, pharmacology and toxicology, genetics, biochemistry and molecular biology, physiology, or microbiology and molecular genetics). This is a great way to get a feel for which program will suit you best. In addition, MSU is a highly collaborative university. Collaboration across departments and between different labs is highly encouraged and there are many opportunities for students to explore different career paths during their time at MSU. Getting a degree at MSU also creates a huge network by virtue of its size.
cons: There is not a ton of institutional support if the PI is unable to support a student's research. In addition, depending on the department, there is not much oversight of a PI's mentoring to graduate students.

review_title: All about who you know or if they like you
job_title: Animal Caretaker in East Lansing, MI
pros: Good pay. Nice campus. Mostly friendly people. Decent benefits. Some perks depending on the department and status level you are. Looks good on paper.
cons: Very early hours. Busy campus. Students get in the way. Pay for parking without guarantee of spot. Hard to reach some people. Almost everything is email based. Most departments don't like outsiders. You can get in and advance if you know someone. Mostly union which doesn't always help you.

review_title: Life as a staffer at MSU
job_title: Information Technoloist in East Lansing, MI
pros: Good work life balance, good benefits, job security. The campus is a beautiful place especially in summer. People are kind of buffered from economic downturns. It's also great if you want to go back to school at MSU, since MSU will cover the cost of education for you and your kids.
cons: If you are not faculty, you are always a second class citizen. Of course faculty have big egos even though their skills don't count for jack in real world operations. Since the staff is unionized, there is no incentive for working harder, so the bright people leave sooner or later. And since the staff is unionized, it is pretty hard to get rid of people you would like to get rid of. Much greater emphasis is placed on faculty development than staff development.

job_title: Computer Science & Engineering Department
pros: A good place to work while enrolled in school. As my position was an assistantship, my tuition was payed for with benefits and a pay check on top of that. The position left plenty of time to do school work along side the job. Lot's of learning opportunities if you take them. If you have ideas on how to improve the departments hardware and software services, they are more than happy to let you take the project on.
cons: Management could actually give more work. Sometimes there is a lot of downtime which is great if you have projects for class, but boring if not. If you are taking this job to help pay for your Masters/PhD program, it might be better to get a RA/TA position for the experience, unless you plan to be in a field related to IT support.

review_title: Great University - Poor Central IT Department
job_title: IT Manager in East Lansing, MI
pros: Great university. Excellent programs for students. Beautiful campus. Wonderful training opportunities.
cons: Unfortunately there's been a revolving door for CIOs over the past 10 years. Recently MSU Central IT brought in a strong CIO to manage all central IT services. Within 2 years they asked her to leave, cut desperately needed programs/projects, and implemented massive cuts to staffing. A full third of the executive leadership within central IT services is now gone, and the CISO is now playing his role and that of the CIO. Knowing that MSU IT was already 5 years behind other Big 10 universities for IT infrastructure, development, and service management this set them back further. If you're looking for an organized, mature, and funded place to work...look elsewhere unfortunately.

review_title: It wasn't exactly what I thought after I got the offer letter !!
job_title: Research Assistant/Teaching Assistant in East Lansing, MI
pros:
1) Teaches you to be  patient
2) You have job security
3) Improves your presentation skills and helps to learn how to sound/look/pretend smart :) 
4) Most people are rewarded with some job after you complete your degree.
cons:
1) Poor management of department to aid students to graduate. You have to figure out all your own.
2) Most faculty does not have funding. You may have to compromise your field of interest and choose a different one instead.
3) Duration to get a PhD is 6 yrs or more . I have seen people quitting even after 5 yrs without getting a PhD 
4) There is no administrative body to monitor how adviser treat his/her research graduate students and a lot of them treat badly.

review_title: hostility to the point of frustration
job_title: Library Assistant II
pros:
Great Pay
Great Benefits
Union Representation
Your hours do not fluctuate much and they did try to work with you to some degree with FMLA claims for any issues that arose. They even provided workplace counseling if you could reach out to them.
cons: Hostile environment towards men. I was singled out and bullied until I left. I have had a nervous breakdown and suffered PTSD from the experience. The Union was basically neutered in their ability to help you one way or another. I could not stand having spit wads thrown at me, being micromanaged by all women supervisors who wanted me to change my voice to a higher pitch to sooth them.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Lansing, MI
pros: Michigan state offers a variety of jobs and most of the people that work there are awesome  I truly enjoyed most of my time there
cons: Just because you've been at the same department for over 30 years does not necessarily make you a good employee or a positive asset for Msu  especially when you don't want to change with the times and you're controlling and you don't give people a chance or believe that they can do what you want them to in their own way and still be productive  and successful when you hire someone you have to trust that they will do what they were hired to do even if it's not exactly the way you would do it

review_title: MSU is big on Sport Events
job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in East Lansing, MI
pros: It is affordable to live here. MSU is big in its minorities, and a the culture of inclusiveness is good. It is a big school, if you are a generalist, you will enjoy a big range of majors going on professionally. The sports events are huge, if you are a sports fan. The neighborhoods are laid back. Good for you, if you like quiet places, no one messes with your peace.
cons: Sports. College students. Period. Nothing else going on. You must really love what you do else, otherwise, you ll get depressed.  Parking situation on-campus is bad. We pay 400$ as employees and we still have to spend 20 minutes every morning to find a spot. Terrible. Public transportation is not that bad, though. If you are into, it.

review_title: Low salaries, work expectations same as corporate world
job_title: Information Technologist II in East Lansing, MI
pros: Flexible time, variety of work, challenge of learning new technologies, fair amount of deadwood to compete against for very limited merit raises, most people have nice work environments. Job security is still a little better than corporate, especially for older IT workers.
cons: The pay is much lower than corporate world (for IT, that is, system administrators and programmers), and while 20 years ago there was low stress in the job to offset that, these days staffing is generally stretched thin, resulting in nearly as much stress as I had in corporate world for most of my career.

review_title: Tons of financial resources for PhD students
job_title: PhD Student in Lansing, MI
pros: Competitive stipend, no hidden fees (the only fee I pay $19 every semester to fund the campus radio station...and that's optional), decent health insurance included, amazing on-campus free hospital (Olin). Oh, and automatic raises! The stipend steadily increases every 2 years. Also lots of "oh no something broke" resources (e.g., stolen laptop grant).
cons: The healthcare referral system with the health insurance leads something to be desired. They refer you out for free-ish, but then the provider often charges you a good bit (even after insurance gets applied). If you can't take care of something via the on-campus healthcare, you're going to pay for outside providers basically as if you were out of pocket, because insurance doesn't cover much.

review_title: "Yeah we don't get paid much but the benefits are great" - People who have never worked anywhere else
job_title: Engineer in East Lansing, MI
pros: Laid back work environment, family friendly, vacation time accrues at 8 hours/mo for the first five years then 12hrs/mo and after ten years 16hrs/mo.  East Lansing is a great place to live and Michigan State offers a lot of multicultural festivals, a performing arts center, Big Ten sports etc. Low cost of living.
cons: Benefits do not include good dental package or any vision. Pay is lower than in industry. The bureaucracy of a large university can be hard to manage and there is rampant nepotism, again something characteristic of universities.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in East Lansing, MI
pros: Great pay, great bennies, great people to work with.  Great culture on the campus.  Where you work may have some difference in what you experience, but 90 percent of the folks I see seem to be happy with their jobs here.  People stay forever.  That means to me that it is good to work here.  It is not super easy to get in, as many jobs stay internal, but more skilled positions go external which means anyone can apply.  Just be sure you meet their minimum requirements or qualifications, otherwise your resume will not get past the human resources department.
cons: Parking can be busy sometimes, with long walks to place of employ.  Winter is a bear in MI.  And when will the overall US economy offer us less than 40 hour full-time work weeks?  Just dreaming.

job_title: Assistant Community Director in East Lansing, MI
pros: Opportunity to run your own building as a grad depending on where you are placed. A lot of the CD's give you autonomy and the opportunity to learn what it truly means to be a leader on campus.
cons: There is a lot of interdepartmental favoritism. Certain staff are invited to join committees while others are not. They will ask you to do many things outside of your job description so it's best to have a clear understanding of your role and know your value to the department

review_title: You can really grow your career here.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in East Lansing, MI
pros: Dealt with cutting edge technology.  Lots of IT peers across campus that are open to share knowledge and ideas with, even though they don't work in your department.  Always room for growth and moving up career wise.  Work hard, you will be given more responsibilities.  Paid university classes as long as you follow the procedure for doing so.  Great benefits at the time.  Great retirement plan options and contribution by the university.
cons: Sometimes too many politics in the department.  Pay was not on par with the public sector.  Some workers have been there a long time and are dead weight.

job_title: MSU Greencoat in East Lansing, MI
pros: This is an active job that often allows you to interact and gain experience working with the general public. Depending on the events that you work at, you may get the opportunity to work outdoors or in an air conditioned/heated building. In addition the starting salary is $10.00 an hour.
cons: During some of the events you may have to stand or go without eating for extended periods of time( 8 hours or more). In addition you may have to deal with confrontational or argumentative members of the public. Lastly you are required to work at all MSU home Football games, but are otherwise free to choose your schedule

job_title: Systems Analyst in East Lansing, MI
pros: Benefits package is better than most in this area.  If you are interested in continuing your education while working then this is a good place to work.  Most departments (depending on management/supervisor) will work with you on job flexibility.
cons: Many positions are union-based.  There are several unions on campus and none seem to benefit the majority of its members.  A good working employee could do better on their own.  Also, not all units pay its employees the same as other units for positions that are similar.  This is definitely a discrepancy that the university needs to address.  Career advancement is possible but rarely happens overnight.  Too often the university will hire from the outside before promoting from within:(

review_title: OISS INSO Summer Part Time Job
job_title: Orientation Leader in East Lansing, MI
pros: Best part of working as an orientation leader at INSO (International New Student Orientation) or previously called IAOP (International Academic Orientation Program) for MSU is the connections you make with new international stuents and fellow leaders and supervisors. The staff member are very friendly, responsible and supportive of students summer schedules. The job is best made for students who would like to make connections and give back to other students.
cons: It is often difficult to open up students to help them as they are going through many changes such as jet lag , legal processes, language barriers etc. However, if you put in the time and effort for students and try to engage with them, most will show improvements.

job_title: Manager in East Lansing, MI
pros: MSU has an outstanding benefits package, including vacation, sick time, family sick time, retirement, and educational assistance.  Work environment/culture depends largely on which department you work for, as MSU is extremely segmented.
cons: Raises are very low, per union contract agreements.  So big and spread out that it often doesn't feel like everyone works for MSU, but rather for the individual department that you are housed in.  Politics at MSU are also pretty rough.  Things do not get done quickly, if at all.  Can be tough to move from dept to dept if you're looking for a new job, unless you know somebody or are applying for a position in your own department.

job_title: Supervisor in East Lansing, MI
pros: Close to home; OK pay; Paid Medical Healthcare
cons: Lack of flexibility; Lack of feedback/performance review; Poor work environment and conditions; Out-dated technology; Lack of training/mentoring; Dental coverage is only OK; APSA Union cannot help you with management issues until you have been at MSU for a year and are no longer a probationary member of the union

job_title: Service Center Representative in East Lansing, MI
pros: Working at Michigan State University will always be a cherish-able memory. I started working as a SCR in my second year of college and worked there ever since I graduated as a student employee. I learned a lot and strengthen my business skills over time. I loved working with people them and making sure they were taken care of. It gave me great pleasure. The job was very flexible as long as you did everything you needed to do.
cons: There were no cons but sometimes student supervisors would let their authority take over. Some didn't know how to handle the power ultimately.

review_title: Rotation program recommended for ChEMS dept
job_title: Research Assistant in East Lansing, MI
pros:
-A decent scope of research in ChEMS dept with a lot of interdisciplinary collaborations
-Most professors in the dept are decent advisor, some of them are great. 
-Abundant resources from the uni and graduate school (seminars, workshops, coffee hour and luncheons) on career development
-A lot of the graduate students are able to start a career with big chemical companies
cons:
-As in most graduate schools, graduate students are underrepresented and powerless in some bad situations. Therefore, choosing a good advisor is vital to your well-being/sanity during the program
-However, one doesn't have the choice of rotating between several labs before choosing a project/advisor. You only get to talk to a few professors and senior graduate students before making the big decision.

job_title: Marketing Director in East Lansing, MI
pros: As a communicator I had a lot of autonomy within the college. The other communicators on campus are for the most part good colleagues. Very good work-life balance. You can grow in the job if you want to. I was able to go to training outside of the university to get the training I wanted.
cons: Small marketing budgets and a belief that higher education does not need to market. Higher ed also has a habit of letting faculty members behave badly and getting away with it. Most faculty are great but the few that aren't can make the work very hard.

job_title: Level IV Student Supervisor in East Lansing, MI
pros: Management is very understanding of your classwork. The Managers above me have always understood how important school was and that it was a first priority over my position at MSU. You are given plenty of time to finish the required materials on a weekly basis and overtime is not required, although sometimes offered.
cons: High Turnover Rate. There are currently two level IV's in the building I work in. there have been a few cases where the other Level IV has left which placed the burden of both positions on myself. During this time it was manageable without overtime, but definitely stressful.

review_title: A nice place for work and life balance
job_title: Research Assistant in East Lansing, MI
pros:
*A comprehensive research institute where you have opportunity to meet researcher in all kinds fields.
*The overall atmosphere is generally relax and peer pressure is low. 
*The living cost in the area is relatively low comparing to big city.
*Beautiful campus view.
cons:
*The engineering program is relatively week comparing to other big ten school.
*Not many interesting research is going on.
*Considering the sluggish job market in Michigan, it is difficult to find intern/jobs nearby.
*You may enjoy the relaxed atmosphere, but it pays when you competing with others in job market.
*The winter is too long and cold.

job_title: Student IT Assistant in East Lansing, MI
pros: Decent salary, friendly coworkers, good location on campus by the bus station, nice working culture, feel like contributing to great project. Chance for raises. Weekly meetings help the programming group stay organized, and are usually well attended. Development is done with CakePHP with an Oracle database back end. Small group of programmers working on projects.
cons: Gets lonely working alone in cubicle when other student employee is not there. Software development system can be frustrating to learn at first. The campus it is on (MSU) can get crowded at times, and as a student it is challenging to budget my time as a computer science student and part time employee.

review_title: Great Place to work for a student
job_title: Web Developer Student in East Lansing, MI
pros: Very flexible to class schedule.  I've been involved in every aspect of web development in the fundraising department at Michigan State.  My boss and his bosses are awesome.  I've had a lot of creative freedom there.  The amount I've learned in just two years is beyond what I've learned in many of my classes.  Working during the summer was a great benefit with such high pay.  I could've been doing retail and folding clothes, instead I got to do what I wanted, and really learn a vast amount of information.  I'm so lucky for looking this job up on myspartancareer.
cons: Not enough opportunity to advance.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in East Lansing, MI
pros: The supercomputing center is good and holds courses periodically to teach computing, visualization, using the computing resources well, etc. Postdoc association holds socials and annual travel award cycle. Sometimes grant writing workshops are offered as well.
cons: Life in East Lansing can be dull. Nearest metro is Detroit, although Lansing has an airport as well. I  work in a nice lab and enjoy my work but I would have liked to see more professional development workshops offered to young scientists. These programs are largely on paper.

review_title: They're making headway to support Postdocs
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in East Lansing, MI
pros:
Decent health care and EAP
Helpful lower administration
Free bus passes for getting around campus
Postdoc community events are funded
cons:
Diversity & Inclusion is a thing, but it's new
Most buildings are not equipped with "family" style bathrooms for changing, etc., or they are well-hidden
The postdoc community is somewhat small
It's not always easy to find places to work or park & bicycling is sporadically supported across campus

review_title: Great place to work.  A lot of employees don't realize how "good we have it" compared to private industry for benefits.
job_title: Analyst in East Lansing, MI
pros: Benefits (not as good as the State, but great compared to private industry). Flexibility (at least in my dept).  Being part of the campus community.  Opportunities for advancement and continued education.
cons: Departments/colleges all function very independently, so there isn't a lot of consistency between departments.  Pros in my dept may not be pros in another dept, and vice versa.  A lot of people grumble and don't appreciate what we have, because they've never worked anywhere else so they think the grass is always greener.

job_title: in East Lansing, MI
pros: Excellent work and life balance.  Generous benefits.  Salary is ok.  Excellent community. Spectacular health care.  Great autonomy.  Limited stress.  Family is important to MSU.
cons: A great deal of staff and faculty on campus are petty, shallow and generally incompetent.  Change on campus is not accepted and mediocrity is the norm.  If you don't rock the boat here you can go far or have an easy job.

job_title: Research Assistant in East Lansing, MI
pros: On campus, you get plenty of resources, like free (or cheap) sports, free music concerts, etc. If you are lucky (like me) you get a decent office with less than 5 people in one room.
cons: The administration give no s...t about the well-being of graduate students. During the course of your PhD they may take some benefits from you. Last year, they wanted to remove prescription drug coverage from our insurance plan (GEU resistance stopped them). This year they changed our health care to a cheper one that many doctors don't accept. So don't expect the benefits to improve.

job_title: Curriculm Specialist in East Lansing, MI
pros: It is a flexible place to work and provides great benefits.  It equips one with good work experience;  it keeps up keep up with technology, and it provides a good blend of  work experiences in regard to budgets reports, writing, and marketing, and graphic design work.
cons: It doesn't provide much over time pay; if needed to work past normal business hours;  you are expected to use flex time or comp time. It is hard to move up, but not impossible.

review_title: Fun to work there as a student
job_title: Usher in East Lansing, MI
pros: You get to watch the events that you're ushering for like basketball games and concerts. The customer service experience that you establish is great because you get to interact with customers and challenge yourself to make the contact time between them and you as positive as possible.
cons: It's not fun getting yelled at for other peoples' bad seats. Not very good communication from supervisors. Ushers don't get radios so when there's a problem, they have to flag down a supervisor without leaving their post (aka stand and wait).

job_title: Outreach Specialist in East Lansing, MI
pros: There are so many phenomenal faculty and researchers at this campus across different colleges and units that there are tremendous collaboration opportunities. MSU's access to resources also facilitates and supports many research initiatives. It is an excellent place for tenure track positions.
cons: As a research institution, there is an obvious weighted emphasis on research production. The academic push to procure grants and publish determines a lot of the attention given and resources allocated to particular projects and initiatives. Be in an academic area where there is interest and opportunity, it will increase your levels of success and happiness with the institution. And be flexible to prioritize your efforts around research.

job_title: Communications Coordinator in East Lansing, MI
pros: They seem to hire a certain group of people. They are great to get along with. I feel it varies within each team but the people who don't quite fit the standard great group of people seem to weed themselves out.
cons: They don't tend to hire from within, which is terrible if you are trying to move up in your own office. It doesn't really seem like they respect their employees sometimes. The upper management can sometimes just walk all over their employees.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in East Lansing, MI
pros:
working time is flexible, you only need to finish your working on time without going to lab very early in the morning.
working environment is comfortable, big campus you can enjoy a jogging all the time.
cons: Compared to top universities in the US, MSU need more intelligent people to make a competitive working environment. The university should spend more money on attracting smart people.

review_title: My experience at MSU Greenline was fun and professional at the same time.
job_title: in East Lansing, MI
pros: The job gives you room to advance through the different ranks. There are montly parties and pizza for lunch once campaign switches over.
cons: One con would be that there is a lack of discipline when it comes to attendance all you have to do is ask someone to take your shift or call off which doesnt give you a representation of the real world.

review_title: Wonderful, lots of responsibilities, good team.
job_title: Teaching Assistant in East Lansing, MI
pros: Always room to grow, people always willing to help. A great community that has the drive to make the world a better place. Grad assistants can get their tuition paid for as well as a stipend.
cons: Time management, long hours, no perks for undergrads. Scheduling can sometimes be an issue due to classes, but for the most part management is easy to work with around your class schedule.

job_title: Business Analyst in East Lansing, MI
pros: Benefits are great, provide tools to take leadership trainings, and very friendly atmosphere
cons: Management turnover can be high at times, changes made without feedback from employees

job_title: in East Lansing, MI
pros: Flexible hours, basically always hiring, in some positions you can listen to music, inside look at something no one really knows about on campus.
cons: Lack of communication means that things get changed a lot for no real reason, most of the supervisors don't actually understand how to do the job their supervising.

review_title: It is what it is for GTAs.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in East Lansing, MI
pros: The students are great and I love the campus.  The health benefits for GTAs are excellent, and the union does a great job working for our benefits.
cons: Salary is meager and the cost for dependents on the healthcare plan is astronomical.  Plus the University keeps trying to take away our benefits (again, it's thanks to the union that we still have them).  Also, trying to make EVERY class online applicable for summer semester; which just doesn't work for some classes (e.g., public speaking).

job_title: Banquet Captain in East Lansing, MI
pros: Those looking on Michigan State University campus for a job that will work with class schedules, not bust your chops for a small mistake, and not pay you minimum wage right off the bat should apply here. The culture is fun, the events can be stressful, but it really isn't that hard to be successful.
cons: With catering you have to expect early mornings and late nights. Beyond that some processes were a little frivolous, but in the end made everything easier.

review_title: Office of Engineering Recruitment, K12 Outreach, and Scholarships
job_title: Engineering Mentor in East Lansing, MI
pros: Working with the office of Engineering Recruitment was both educational and engaging; as a student, I was able to learn more about several engineering systems while working alongside several high-level engineering scholars. The pay and benefits were more than satisfactory for the position, and both my supervisor, boss, and co-workers were open and friendly.
cons: On occasion the workload could be imbalanced among employees, with some having a significant amount more work assigned and done, despite having the same position, title, and benefits.

job_title: Environmental Science TA, English Tutor, Writing Tutor in Lansing, MI
pros: Hours are always flexible and there are so many opportunities for academic student jobs within the university. These jobs pay more than the minimum wage.
cons: You can't go over a certain number of hours every pay period, which can be annoying sometimes, especially if you have more than one job at a time. This is a law that MSU can't bypass though, so I don't really expect them to do anything about it.

job_title: Operations Coordinator in East Lansing, MI
pros: Generous paid benefits and retirement contributions. Strong sense of community
cons: Full-time turnover is very low, which subsequently makes promotions difficult. Benefits keep eroding to address constant budget woes, both external (reduced government funding, COVID-19) and self-inflicted (Nassar)

job_title: Student Technical Assistant in East Lansing, MI
pros: The people are wonderful and they work with you to schedule when you need to. The pay is good for a more simpler job and all in all the job is convenient. They have a great cafeteria where you can get many things and go on breaks to relax.
cons: There are other opportunities in nearby similar jobs that do pay higher though. Other than that, I do not have much anything else to say.

job_title: Research Assistant in East Lansing, MI
pros:
Michigan state has a very large and beautiful campus. It has a welcoming environment. People are generally very nice here. Michigan state has a lot of highly ranked academic programs, such as education, supply chain, nuclear physics. The management of the university is very efficient and effective.

Good benefits, job security.

Michigan State has very good basketball and football programs. So if you enjoy sports you will be very happy here. The cost of living at East Lansing is low. You can also have a lot of fun being in a college town.
cons: Budget problem like most of the public universities.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Lansing, MI
pros: The campus is very big and beautiful, most of the advisors are nice to students. The sports teams of msu are really good, especially football. The university dining halls are very nice.
cons: The graduate programs are not competitive enough, most of the graduate level course works are useless and boring. The price level is relatively higher than any other small cities. The university is crowded with too many Chinese undergraduates.

job_title: Assistant Professor STEM in East Lansing, MI
pros: - flexible work schedule as a tenure track prof
cons:
- Central Michigan is a terrible place to live (lack of culture, high crime, public space/land, weather)
- Lack of access to a good airport
- Management is awful at all levels, university wide
- Larry Nassar fallout has crippled all levels of leadership
- State and federal funding is drying up
- high quality faculty and admins are jumping ship at an alarming rate
- Enrollment is dropping
- faculty increasingly being asked to do more with less
- endless meetings about nothing

job_title: Resident Mentor in East Lansing, MI
pros: The main pro is that as Mentors we received free room and board. Interacting with people and a few other small privileges such as early enrollment.
cons: Poor communication and organization. Bad leadership and incompetence. The structure of the organization is archaic and does little to actually serve the community it is trying to engage with and instead just worries more about looking good on paper.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in East Lansing, MI
pros:
values interdisciplinarity
decentralized power structure
competitive faculty salaries
lots of internal resources and opportunities for professional development
strong emphasis on its land-grant mission
cons: MSU is a very large organization both in terms of personnel, units, and geographic space.  So, there is a very real chance of missing out on opportunities on campus simply because there are so many things going on all of the time.

review_title: College of Engineering - Respect your support staff
job_title: Technician in East Lansing, MI
pros: good hours, great boss, comfortable work environment
cons: Higher ups aren't planning for the future, enrolling more and more students without budgeting for the increased load of technicians and other support staff. When senior technicians retire (soon) the college is going to be scrambling to keep labs, classes, and research functional, let alone running smoothly.

job_title: Information Technologist I in East Lansing, MI
pros: It seems like it's nearly impossible to get fired... so you can slip by doing minimal work indefinitely. Good work/life balance (though it's hard not to have that when you can do almost nothing and not be fired).
cons:
MSU is too big, and has too much duplication, especially when it comes to IT services. The bureaucracy makes it nearly impossible to get anything done in a timely manner. There's basically no communication between departments, and nobody seems to know what is going on in the university outside of their own department. It's pretty much a mess from the top down.

From a compensation standpoint, raises don't even keep up with the cost of inflation. The union might keep you in your job, but the contracts they negotiate are garbage which results in the raises being an effective pay cut each year in terms of actual purchasing power. The health insurance is okay, though they refuse to cover any dependent that has the option of getting insurance from their employer for less than a certain dollar amount per year out of pocket, even if that insurance is terrible. Really drives home the fact that the university doesn't care about their employees or their families. The dental insurance is terrible, you get to choose between a plan that is only accepted by one dentist in the area and a plan that only pays 50% of services. No vision coverage, unless you pay for it out of pocket. They make you pay for parking as an employee. Nothing like charging your workers for the privilege of coming to work, right? Information on other benefits (like tuition assistance) that they tout is so hard to find and confusing if you do find it that it becomes almost impossible to understand what is available and how to get it. Almost seems like they're making it intentionally confusing just to keep people from using it.

job_title: Mechanical Engineer in East Lansing, MI
pros:
I have been here five years so here is my rundown of what it's like working at MSU.  As is usual with academia pay is lower than what's typical in the private sector.  This is exacerbated by the fact that MSU is a state school in the midwest.  That said there are a lot of great benefits to working here.  First, I never work overtime.  I am paid for 40 hours and I work for 40 hours.  You might make more at another job but I wouldn't be surprised if you're working 50+ hours a week to get it.  Second, there is a generous leave policy.  Most people I know get 3-4 weeks of vacation days a year, plus they give unlimited sick time, which is very nice.  Coworkers are a nice group of people, very kind, diverse and intelligent.  We don't have to worry about profits so you don't have a manager breathing down your neck all the time.  Cost of living is very low in the Lansing area.  You can get a gorgeous house here for little money, be minutes from work, and maybe an hour and a half from the beach.  Discounted tuition for family members and a very generous 401k match.
 
Basically if you want to have a nice life with a great work/life balance and relaxing work environment you will like it here.  Definitely a good place to raise a family if that's your thing.  If you are aggressive and want to claw your way up the corporate ladder this is the wrong place for you.
cons: Limited opportunities for advancement.  Many people have been in the same role for years with a standard cost of living adjustment every year.  No bonuses.

job_title: Chemistry Graduate Student in East Lansing, MI
pros: The people in the graduate office and in the general chemistry office are there to help and support you. If you are a PhD student, you are guaranteed a TA position to act as your funding for five years.
cons: The department cares more about itself and the money its professors bring in than its students. They allow abusive professors to continue taking in students despite multiple complaints. They do not want to support you even if they say they do. Actions speak louder than words and the chem dept at MSU is all words.

review_title: Good job for a college student
job_title: Teaching Assistant, College Or University in East Lansing, MI
pros: Working part-time as a teaching assistant at Michigan State is a great job for a college student. The scheduling is fair and constant, and it looks really good on a resume to be a teaching assistant for a college class.
cons: No real opportunity for advancement. Pay is not amazing, and you're stuck without a job during summer months and school breaks. Sometimes the work can be stressful and frustrating.

review_title: 3 years of fun but it's all the same after a while.
job_title: Teaching Assistant, College Or University in East Lansing, MI
pros: Friendly work environment, working mostly with people of the same age, pay is better than average for not having a degree.
cons: It often feels like you are taking another class and you can't set most of your schedule to benefit you. Sometimes I had wished that I had worked in a less mentally demanding job where I could have just gone on autopilot and then get back to homework.

job_title: Student Technician in East Lansing, MI
pros: Flexible hours, can work whenever we want, lots of time off for classes and or exams, as long we show up. one week I only put in an hour of work on my time sheet they were still ok with it.
cons: It's hard having a job on campus I'd you have a difficult major because there is no time to put in lots of hours.

job_title: in East Lansing, MI
pros: Benefits were great. Plenty of time off if in supervisor union. 10% to retirement on top of salary. Some educational benefits, but were decreasing when I left.
cons: It's more important that you appease the right people than do your job, even more so than in industry. There are still some people at high levels who only have high school educations. Lots of power struggles in management. I had five bosses over five years.

job_title: Dining Room Manager in Lansing, MI
pros:
Outstanding benefits
Lots of trust from my personal manager, I feel empowered to make decisions in my location and to try out new ideas.
Paid holidays
cons: As with any large institution, there are several decisions that come from "up top". These are not always communicated effectively.

review_title: Michigan State is an amazing place to work if you love higher education.
job_title: Student Clerk in East Lansing, MI
pros: The people who work here are above average intelligence and know how to run a University.  It is a great place for students to get jobs too.
cons: The only downside is the snow in the winter.  Campus is quite large so it rough to travel on campus sometimes, but CATA helps a lot.

review_title: Great place to work around a students schedule
job_title: Office Assistant in East Lansing, MI
pros: Michigan State University is a great place to work as a student because they are very fitting to work around your class schedule. You don't have to work many hours and they pay at a competitive rate.
cons: The jobs can often be lower level and some what monotonous. They offer a very low sense of identity about the tasks you complete when working there.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in East Lansing, MI
pros: They have good benefits and we aren't expected to work much more than 40 hours per week, which is nice when you have a family. Also, there is a lot of diversity on campus.
cons: Lansing, Michigan isn't the most thriving city, but most people have lived in the area their entire lives. The politics and beaurocracy within the University are surprising.

review_title: Nice place to work, nice people
job_title: Mechanical Engineer in East Lansing, MI
pros: Friendly midwestern people, not too stressful, lots of educational opportunities, generous leave and benefits.  Very interesting technology and hardware.  Very low cost of living.  Safe area, very family friendly place.
cons: It's in a small town in Michigan.  Limited opportunities for advancement.  Limited salary.  Winters are terrible.  You need a PhD if you really to advance in this organization.

job_title: Health Care Assistant (MA) in East Lansing, MI
pros: Great benefits, wonderful perks and paid vacation/sick/personal days. One of the best perks is the half off tuition for staff and their families.
cons: My first 6 months were great! It went down hill fast over the next two and a half years. The workload they assign you, should be assigned to three others as well! They offer nothing to make up for the stress they put on their employees. Also have to pay monthly or yearly parking!

review_title: This position at MSU is a great opportunity to build professional communication skills.
job_title: Campus Living Services Student Supervisor in East Lansing, MI
pros: The campus features many intertwined departments all working together to achieve a common goal. Because of that there are a lot of opportunities to work with other departments. And for students it is a great opportunity to build your resume while working on campus and trying to do well in classes at the same time!
cons: As a student sometimes it is hard to fit in work and class, and sometimes scheduling can be annoying. But nothing is too bad.

job_title: Student Cook Supervisor in East Lansing, MI
pros: Good people on the job, management always does their best to support decisions of supervisors and all employees. Payroll is fair and so is job placement
cons: There is no way to advance into a true career, unless you want to stay at the university all your life, which in 9.5/10 times, people do not

review_title: Great College Job and Learning Experience, Not a Career
job_title: Supervisor in East Lansing, MI
pros: Those who work hard and push themselves to succeed can escalate through the ranks quickly.  Lot's of leadership experience to be gained and a decent way to pay the bills in College.
cons: Management can be very calloused towards employee needs and many of them have an ego.  Getting promoted can be a very political process as well since in many cases student managers regulate the promotion process.

job_title: Human Resources Office & Marketing Assistant in East Lansing, MI
pros: Michigan State, for me especially as a student, is so convenient. They work around my class schedule and make sure I am given the amount of hours I requested. There's endless opportunities here at MSU for career advancement. There's also a lot of room for growth to move up into a full time position.
cons: The only con I would have to say about working at MSU is the low pay. Most student employees are only paid minimum wage with a tiny raise after each year you work.

review_title: A big and beautiful university to study and work at
job_title: Mechanical Engineer in Chicago, IL
pros:
The campus is big and beautiful (better than UMich, IMHO).  
The  lab I worked in is in a  leading position in the world.
 The living expense is not high, the graduate assistantship is enough to support  your basic life in the univerity town.
cons:
The Winter there is horrible, too much snows. 
Large number of students(>45000), the trafic and sidewalk is often crowded between classes.
The university town is small and boring, few attractions and nice Asian food restarounts nearby.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Lansing, MI
pros: Really great teaching experience in MSU. They also provide really good health insurance for all the employees and pay for the graduate students courses up to 9 credits per semester.
cons: Some courses do require you to spend lots of time in it to grade a lot of stuff. They barely increase your overall salary.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in East Lansing, MI
pros: no one pays attention to your coming or goings, you can work when you want and it is a casual environment
cons: Grad students are left to themselves with little or no oversight often, leaving you either with nothing to do to get toward graduation. Then Grad students are expected to work 80-120 hour weeks to make deadlines.

review_title: You take the bad with the good.
job_title: Information Technology in East Lansing, MI
pros: Working here is very safe... people don't often get fired. You have good benefits here, too.
cons: There is a definite lack of motivation to make anything change across the university. You will absolutely find better compensation almost anywhere else for a comparable job.

review_title: Wonderful experience working as a student (Residential and Hospitality Services)
job_title: Guest Services Student Supervisor in East Lansing, MI
pros: There were opportunities for advancement as a student, which gave me a lot of beneficial experience. I especially benefited from professional development opportunities (e.g., a behavioral based interviewing seminar). I loved interacting with students, their families, prospective students, and alumni.
cons: Management was constantly changing - I had four different bosses in 3.5 years.

job_title: Technical Aide in East Lansing, MI
pros: Very accommodating for working students and a good job for learning construction process for students. You can get a good exposure and will feel more comfortable as the environment is not competitive like in industry.
cons: The work is purely small scale for those working in maintenance services because they only do renovation and small jobs most of the time.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in East Lansing, MI
pros: Michigan State University is, bar none, the best employer I have ever had the opportunity to work for. With competitive pay and benefits, even as a graduate student, I have absolutely no complaints and would go back in a heartbeat.
cons: The only negative was, as a graduate student, you were always "guaranteed" a teaching position, but I never had any trouble getting one to cover my semester and tuition.

review_title: Service Center Representative - Easy on-campus job
job_title: Service Center Representative in East Lansing, MI
pros: They work well with your schedule and the job is easy to learn. Its good money that you are close to, and you do easy desk stuff. Most of the time you are sitting around or doing a simple task. Great for taking classes and earning money
cons: The management can be a little tough on getting time off sometimes. Also a little boring.

job_title: Account Executive in East Lansing, MI
pros:
- Learn a lot about Newspapers and advertising
- Make more money based on how hard you want to work
- Can make a LOT of money working just 15 hours a week (some make $1000 ever two weeks.. not bad for a part-time job)
cons:
- Managers are inconsiderate
- Low starting compensation

review_title: Don't let modest benefits allure you from the fact that MSU will stifle and kill your motivation and creativity.
job_title: Librarian in East Lansing, MI
pros: Vacation time & Health Benefits
cons:
Library administrators lack leadership skills; act as paternalists
Library administrative culture of marginalism and idea theft
Barriers to promotion and professional development
Administration has no strategic vision or plan, it's laughable
No accountability in the library; they "don't believe in numbers"

review_title: Don't expect anyone to make a decision. Ever.
job_title: Information Technologist in East Lansing, MI
pros: It's managed like a bunch of different companies, and each has its own cultural differences. It's fairly easy to move from one part to another. Work/life balance can be good, depending on where you are. Benefits are decent; time off especially good.
cons: Little opportunity for career advancement. Low pay. Micro management is very common, as are faculty with over-sized egos.

job_title: Programmer Analyst in East Lansing, MI
pros: The best thing about MSU is the workers.  They really believe in teamwork and helping each other.
cons: The management needs to be changed.  They only focus on themselves, and not the big picture, provide little guidance to staff and belittle staff on a daily basis.  Management is more concerned about creating drama, then solving problems.  Staff turnover is extremely high and no one cares..  Do something about trying to retain your long term staff.

review_title: Great place to work for an undergrad.
job_title: Research Assistant in East Lansing, MI
pros: I was able to find a job at Michigan State as undergrad pretty easily. I had a few different research jobs, and as long as you find a professor that is friendly and understanding, the work is enjoyable. In general MSU professors are pretty down-to-earth. It is easy to make lasting relationships with them.
cons: I've heard from my professors and advisors that because of MSU's large size the structure is fairly bureaucratic. It takes awhile to approve things. Pay attention to deadlines.

review_title: It is a great experience working in Michigan State University as a Teaching Assistant
job_title: Teaching Assistant in East Lansing, MI
pros: People around the campus are friendly. East Lansing is a convenient town. You could go to everywhere in a short time.
cons: Work load is really heavy. The pay for graduate assistants is OK but definitely not top ones around US. There are a lot of international students.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in East Lansing, MI
pros: The students are by far the best part of working at MSU! To see them learn, develop and grow into their own is extremely rewarding.
cons: MSU is a huge place and because there are so many silos, it takes a lot to get things done in a timely and efficient manner. Like more higher ed institutions, staff is challenged to do more with less.

review_title: I have learned a lot about myself and about academia.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Scientist in East Lansing, MI
pros:
I have had wonderful mentors who have helped me become better at science.    
The environment is generally friendly and collaborative. 
There are many resources available to accomplish different aspects of research.
cons: Sexual harassment claims are not taken seriously and it breeds a hostile and less productive atmosphere.   Victims are afraid to come forward because the accused are not investigated seriously and therefor not held accountable.

job_title: Web Developer Student in East Lansing, MI
pros: Being a student it allows for an excellent work/school schedule, while providing an awesome work experience in your field.
cons: Being a student you are often looked down upon by professors and other faculty. You are often inundated with relatively stupid requests by professors/faculty who do not know what they are doing.

job_title: in East Lansing, MI
pros:
flexible hours, and if you need a day off it was never an issue
caring and fun bosses
useful knowledge for future jobs.
cons: work can sometimes get very tedious, it's a very regular day in and day out job. It wasn't exactly what was advertised either, not much graphic work.

job_title: Production Aide in East Lansing, MI
pros: The people are warm and welcoming.  Very personable.  The work is simple and not demanding.  Hours are extremely flexible to other activities/
cons: As a student there is not a lot of room to earn more money.  A lot of the difficult work is performed by full time employees.  After a certain amount of time, there is also not a lot of professional growth.

review_title: work very well to balance a student lifestyle
job_title: Production Staff in East Lansing, MI
pros: Your bosses and fellow employees are all students, except for the building management, so it is very easy to quickly learn and get comfortable with what is expected of you. An enjoyable place to be especially with all the opportunities to work unique events along with the traditional games that have always been held there.
cons: No real problems besides some of the positions for the shifts require long hours of standing in one position.

job_title: Research Assistant in East Lansing, MI
pros:
- Flexible hours
- Amazing letters of rec
- Great mentors
- Ability to learn many office related skills

I worked as research staff for one of the College of Nursing professors for two years. I was compensated fairly, received two raises/promotions, and learned finance, grant-writing, and research skills. Great place to work, great work environmnt
cons:
- Could be boring at times
- Wasn't able to be full time due to the cost of paying benefits

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in East Lansing, MI
pros: I worked as a graduate research assistance. A great deal depends on your advisor and your relationship. Also if there is funding. Overall a laid back environment with very high expectations.
cons: You need to be self-motivated and a self-starter, there is often a lack of clear direction. Each department runs differently. Personality and politics can get in the way. There are things people get away with in academia that would get them fired in a heartbeat in the private sector.

review_title: Great resources for doing scientific research.
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in East Lansing, MI
pros: Easy to set up collaborations across departments and younger faculty are very eager to conduct research.  MSU is a great college town and the students really bring a great spirit to the community. Many students are interested in contributing to scientific research and do a really stellar job doing so.
cons: Very difficult to get health insurance as a Post Doc.  Rates are pretty high, and no other benefits are included, even if federally funded.

job_title: Student Clerical Assistant in East Lansing, MI
pros: My job schedule is very flexible since I am working while I am still a student at Michigan State University, very friendly employees, thorough training and given responsibilities immediately
cons: There are not many cons! There isn't much of a company culture, but this is only due to the fact that I am a student assistant, rather than an employee.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Lansing, MI
pros: Depends on the professor.  Some are very aware of the amount of time you have at your disposal as a graduate student.  Others are oblivious and unreasonable.  Benefits are okay.
cons: Salary is extremely low.  By far the lowest in the Big Ten.  Health insurance is through Aetna, and you must visit Olin Health Clinic for all of your primary care needs.  This is awful.

review_title: The world of academia when you're support staff
job_title: in East Lansing, MI
pros:
Getting to work with students.
Decent Benefits. (Dental is bad, health is great.)
Vacation time.
Educational release time.
cons: No raises in the past couple of years for entire departments but the supervisors in those departments salaries have grown exponentially.

review_title: University run by people who don't understand or care about either teaching or research
job_title: Professor in East Lansing, MI
pros: At a university this size you will find SOME good people at every level.
cons: Toxic bro/sports culture among the students. Stupid long-term policy of promoting administrators from within. Idiotic legacy of hiring presidents who have no experience with academia, or at least with teaching and research. Obsession with metrics and image at the expense of substance. Currently imploding in the wake of the Nassar scandal, with continual mismanagement. Morale among faculty and staff  in the toilet.

review_title: Great on campus job while in school.
job_title: Service Center Representative in East Lansing, MI
pros: I was given responsibility and there is great potential to move up in this position. My supervisors were all very nice and supportive.
cons: The Job can get boring at times. Customers sometimes have strange request and unrealistic demands of you. I would not recommend the all night shift in Owen Hall.

job_title: Student Assistant in East Lansing, MI
pros: Great experience, very flexible, they value your education over your time put in work. My supervisors are very caring and polite. They do not put you down for your mistake but help you learn from them.
cons: Working with lazy student co-workers. Not much room for growth depending on your field. Very competitive application process due to mass amount of students looking for jobs.

review_title: Graduate Student in the Department of Chemical Engineering and Material Science
job_title: Graduate Student in East Lansing, MI
pros: Strong computational research groups with a vast amount of computational resources. Some professors are very active (mostly younger profs.)  Good healthcare. Job fair twice a year at least.
cons: Currently (2017), there are many inactive professors in the chemical engineering side, as long as you steer away from those and choose younger professors, you'd be fine. On the material science side, I heard there are needs for more instrument though.

job_title: Chef in Lansing, MI
pros:
- Large, diverse student and employee community
- Regular schedule, not too much necessary overtime outside of fall opening
- Good benefits package and regular salary increases, decent base salary
- Good vacation and sick time accruals and 3 personal days every year
- Opportunities to be creative and set your own goals
cons:
- Some difficulties working with union restrictions
- very back and forth handling of COVID -19, not forthcoming communication from university and divisional leadership leading into furloughs

job_title: in Lansing, MI
pros:
1) Awesome...Good supply chain program and FREE!( I have scholarship- 100% plus GA) . 
2) Good interface and relationship with industry.
cons: No Consulting exposure and poor academic standards and could give more focus on Operations and production.  Too focused on Supply chain management and no interface with IB and Management consulting

review_title: This has been the perfect college position.
job_title: Technologist in East Lansing, MI
pros: The other staff are fun to work with, the duties of the job are interesting, and you learn a lot about both MRI and how to act professionally in a medical setting.
cons: The patients can be rude and trying, occasionally when the department gets behind on patients things can get very hectic. Attention to detail is very important as well.

job_title: Student Programmer in East Lansing, MI
pros: Learned a ton, treated well, I'm very fortunate to have the experience they offered me in order to get a professional position.
cons: A little too nice, sometimes they aren't stern enough to actually force one to begin working. However, this is also a nice thing, as you are never punished.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in East Lansing, MI
pros: There is a flexible schedule depending on your availability, nice salary in the form of  paycheck plus tuition plus health insurance and a great work environment.
cons: Grading can become challenging. Freshmen courses usually have many students and grading can take a large portion of your time. It doesn't apply to higher levels as much.

job_title: Office Assistant III in East Lansing, MI
pros: My current department is an absolute joy to work for and with. They are extremely supportive of my professional and personal goals.
cons: I have worked in other departments who are inflexible and could not care less about you working toward a goal, like pursuing a degree. I worked in a medical center at MSU and they do not allow educational release or care that you may have family obligations, such as taking your child to school.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in East Lansing, MI
pros: You will have the opportunity to work with well known and well respected researchers, access to the university's considerable resources (data processing, access to journals through the library, travel funding to attend conferences); overall, university support for graduate students is good, and even though it is a large school there is a relatively close-knit graduate student community
cons:
TA/GA financial support can vary quite a bit from department to department

Limited opportunities to teach in class

review_title: It may change for the better
job_title: Professor in East Lansing, MI
pros: It had a reasonable reputation for research
cons:
It has suffered from having inept presidents who were not themselves scholars for decades.
There is hope with the new president. However, most members of the board of trustees are corrupt or useless or both.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in East Lansing, MI
pros: The culture is young, vibrant and energizing. The university offers lots of great resources for the students and staff. One can live a really good life working here. There is an awesome work/life balance and career opportunities.
cons: There are lots of politics. Being a largely liberal university (which there's nothing wrong with) it brings unique challenges to every position the university offers that probably isn't as prominent in comparable private sector positions.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in Lansing, MI
pros: MSU has one of the most beautiful campus of the US. Students are friendly, and come from all over the world.
cons: The weather is a problem in MSU. You may suffer more than 5 months snow season at MSU. Also, students are quite like sports, maybe a pro or a con.

job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in East Lansing, MI
pros: Access to novel research, vast library resources, high level equipment
cons: Experience will vary depending upon degree, department, advisor, personality, life goals, previous experience, phase of Jupiter, life style, medical conditions, peers, living arrangement, etc. It is difficult to say how any one person will react to the experience. It is difficult to do, go in with the knowledge that it will be hard. But you will also have your own unique kind of hard.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Lansing, MI
pros:
The people at MSU were very friendly and  I got a wide exposure to people with different skill sets
There are a  lot of diverse opportunities which can help you find a job that will suit your interests and skills.
cons:
I was still in learning phase, some initial training would have been really helpful. 
Also, being an international, was restricted in work due to Visa issues (not necessarily a problem with the employer)

review_title: Pay is almost bare minimum for living in east Lansing.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in East Lansing, MI
pros: It's a challenging atmosphere, intellectually. I am given health insurance. I am very independent when it comes to research, and that is encouraged
cons: The pay is little. It compares to minimum wage at full time. It is an unwritten rule that researchers work at least 40 hours a week but we only get paid for 20 hours

job_title: Receptionist in East Lansing, MI
pros: The job is very flexible and you can do what you want at your desk as long as you do your job at the same time.
cons: Having to work the entire night and deal with intoxicated students. There is also the issue of not being able to leave the desk.

review_title: Not getting paid enough for the amount of work
job_title: Administrative Assistant in East Lansing, MI
pros: Good benefits, relaxed schedule, good workplace environment, good about lunch breaks and taking time off
cons: Overworked me for the amount of money I was being paid, snarky management

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Lansing, MI
pros: Always got assistantships in the form of TA or RA positions
cons: Professors not helpful. No support system for the students. Everyone is aware that it's hard to get a job, but not very much is being done to train students about non-academic careers. Lots of internal politics at the upper level; affects students' well-being but faculty are untouchable.

job_title: Project Manager in East Lansing, MI
pros: The work culture is very collaborative and rewarding for employees looking to explore their careers.
cons: Willingness to allow new approaches to business processes or practices is limited and planning for the future of the organization is rather short sited.

job_title: Mentor in East Lansing, MI
pros: Good work environment and professional experience.  Having a floor of 30 students to supervisor is a great way to learn about yourself.
cons: Having 30 students needeing you at all times of the day can really ware on your own school work and accomplishments

review_title: Very big with lots of opportunities, not good for grad CS majors
job_title: Graduate Researcher in East Lansing, MI
pros:
- People are very nice and helpful
- East Lansing is completely dedicated to MSU students
- Very safe environment
cons:
- Everyone in Engineering grad school is either socially awkward, clinically depressed or both.
- The system allows for very incompetent people to graduate with MS or PhDs. 
- If you are not going into the PhD or into academia, everyone will see you as inferior.

job_title: Epidemiologist in Lansing, MI
pros: job security, 7 pay steps, regular performance reviews, some professional development, great colleagues and supervisors,  access to large administrative datasets, decent vacation time
cons: not much room for growth, tuition reimbursement ~1 graduate credit in Epi per year, mostly surveillance based positions, scarce resources

job_title: Research Associate in East Lansing, MI
pros: There is a lot of scheduling flexibility in my current role, and I have been able to work completely from home for the time being. I work with a small group, so I am thankful that I have enjoyed working with everyone.
cons: MSU also has great health and retirement benefits, although as a Research Associate, I only qualified for the retirement matching because my previous employer provided match.

job_title: Department Aide in East Lansing, MI
pros: One of the best small office environments I have ever work in.  Management definitely has the employee's best interest in mind.
cons: As with any large organization, the amount of paperwork and time to complete simple tasks can be at times overbearing.

job_title: Research Assistant in East Lansing, MI
pros: The health plan is not bad although it doesn't cover dental insurance. The paid salary of graduate students are more than enough compared to other universities.
cons: There are always some hidden fees everywhere. Here graduate students at engineering have to pay this stupid engineering fee every semester.
